blog.description: President Obama will soon be sworn into office, and whether you voted for him or not, he's everybody's president. What do you want him to remember in his second term? We will feature your responses in our inauguration coverage!
blog.title: Dear Mr. President
blog.name: inauguration2013

posts.caption:

What do you want President Obama to remember in his second term? Share your message at NPR’s Dear Mr. President.

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

I didn’t vote for you because I’ve decided never again to vote for either major political party. Having seen enough presidential election cycles, it is obvious that it is the same game being played each time, with a same result.

We never get an individual that can speak freely. We never get new ideas, just the same old ones that are owned by one party or another. We never get honesty or clarity. We never get full disclosure. We are never told the difficult things that are true, but that we don’t want to hear. We never get inspiration.

Remember that you have a rare opportunity, that you will never get again. Don’t be a politician. Be a President. I dare you.

Signed,
Jason from Mosier, OR

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Mr. President,
You and I share a faith that changes society. We follow a man who told us not to aim for power, money, and selfish interests; but to remember our own history of suffering, protect the orphan and widow, welcome the immigrant. I know you hold this radical faith dear to you, and it is what has given me hope. Remember Jesus’ third way, and keep being creative.

Signed,
Maria from Philadelphia, PA

Dear Mr. President,

I voted for you.

Mr. President, Public Enemy #1 is now, clearly, CLIMATE CHANGE. That means it should be immediately moved under the auspices of the Department of Defense. Using even a small portion of our military budgets to pursue new energy technologies and carbon sequestration technologies, we will be able to ramp up the transition away from fossil fuels more expeditiously than otherwise possible. Recent advances in nanotechnology, such as the discovery of Higgs Boson and the Buckminsterfullerene offer great promise for energy development. Invest in livingry, not weaponry, as Buckminster Fuller said, and we will be able to stem the tide of environmental distruction on united space planet earth!

Signed,
Pat Ravasio from Marin County (of course!)

Dear Mr. President,

I didn’t vote for you.

Because I do not live in a swing state, I chose to support a presidential candidate with whom my political convictions more closely aligned. That said, I’m a pragmatists and spent the better part of a week campaigning on your behalf in a closely contested swing state during the last days of the campaign.

When people asked “are you better off than you were four years ago?”, my answer was a resounding “yes”. I am more educated, my partner and I enjoy increasing equality throughout this great nation and I am enjoying my current job more than any I have had before. It does not pay as well as I would like but student loan reform means I am not suffocating under the burden of crushingly high monthly payments.

The question, “are you better now than you were 4 years ago?” was the most disastrous question of the 2012 election cycle. Instead, we should ask ourselves, “Are we better than we were 30, 40 or 50 years ago?”

One bit of hope: we have made great steps forward in protecting our environment for future generations. That said, we can do far more to be good stewards of our natural resources and to emerge as a global leader on what is our generation’s most pressing issue.

Equality is more difficult to gauge. At the state level, women’s reproductive rights are under increasing attack. Our nation’s prosperity increasingly drives a gap between the wealthy and the middle-class. When wealthy bankers nearly collapsed our financial system, we offered government assistance without public accountability for reckless leadership. At the same time, rather than offering help to our nation’s neediest—those who rely on charity or our increasingly weak social services—we choose to scrutinize what they have done that resulted in their state of neediness. This, sir, is not equality.

So, while I appreciate your emergent support for LGBT equality, I hope that you will be more vocal and forceful on issues of economic equality. I urge you to fight for the economic success of impoverished families throughout our country—whether they be in rural Appalachia or in Englewood on Chicago’s south side. Listen to the needs of these communities but also to the solutions they envision and the solutions that have been tried and tested.

Finally, thank you for your service to this Nation. I am proud to have you as my President and as our Commander in Chief. I wish you and our nation great success in the coming four years.

Signed,
David C. Dubxury from Chicago, IL
